content.description: A 60 foot flake that overhangs slightly the whole way. Grab a jug, layback to the next jug, rinse, repeat. If this route was located in Rumney it would be a contender for one of the best 10d's there, and you would have to wait in line for it even on weekdays. On its own it is an amazing route, and better still is its proximity to the crag's classic 5.12. If you head up this with 16 or so draws you can also hang draws on "Danen Direct" on your way down making it the perfect warmup.
content.protection:
7-8 bolts.   Stick clip the first bolt. 

  NOTE: Bolt #4 is spinning in its hole and can not be loosened or tightened. It may or may not hold a fall. Fortunately the distance between bolt 3 and bolt 5 is reasonable and the climber is unlikely to hit anything in the event of catastrophe.
content.location: In the middle of the Waternomee main wall, this is the obvious flake that leads to the top of the cliff.

content.description: A silly but fun link up. Use long slings to climb the first five or six (depending on drag) bolts of The Spirit of Waternomee, and transition to the resting jug that marks the rest on Danen Direct. From the jug execute the final boulder problem of Danen Direct and finish on that anchor.  Its a fun route, but probably only do this one if you've run out of stuff in the area.
content.location: Start on the large flake of Spirit of Waternomee, finish on the final boulder problem of Danen Direct.

content.description:
Unique and high quality sport route that carves across the top of the Waternomee amphitheater.  Not your everyday climb. Ride the arete, try to stay in rhythm, drop your feet below the lip if you dare. Save some fuel for a tricky section at the top. 9 bolts.  

 Gets 3 stars in the Sykes book; I don't disagree but for MP I gave it 3 out of 4. The 10a rating felt spot-on. Tricky for an onsight because it's so weird, but ultimately the moves are on grade.

 Note: This sucker goes way the hell right from the start, so cleaning on the lower would be impossible.
content.location: All the way left. Look for the bolts trimming the edge of the imposing steep wall. End at a tree with crispy disconcerting TAT in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Locate the overhanging corner on the right side of Waternomee, make weird moves past a few bolts up to an interesting mantle to the anchor.
content.location: To the right of the 5.5 choss chimney, this is the furthest right bolted route at waternomee.

content.description: Climb gigantic loose looking blocks up a wide corner towards a steep feature at the top. Bring long slings and climb with care. Having not climbed this one but others in the area before they were clean, I'd hesitate to say this one is going to feel like sport climbing.
content.location: Start to the right of Danen Direct out a right trending traverse

content.description: Start on Danen Direct and climb through the easier low crux to the nice resting jug, from the jug make one move up and transition to the last bolt of The Spirit of Waternomee. This link-up follows the path of least resistance for Danen Direct's finish, however it skips the hard crux at the end making for a pumpy but friendly 5.12a. A great choice if you can't quite figure out the last bit of beta for Danen Direct, or are just looking for something with a little less sting in it.
content.location: Start on Danen Direct, but finish on the end of Waternomee

content.description: The Eyeless in Gaza of Kinsman Notch, this route will be on you to the very end. Climb the slightly overhanging bolt line through pumpy edges to a distinct low crux that ends at a nice resting jug. From the resting jug follow the original line rightward through a technical boulder problem that yields to good beta and well timed rest.
content.location: The bolt line right of The Spirit of Waternomee.

content.description: Burly, primarily awkward sport climb at the bottom of the Waternomee climbing area.  Towards the top of the steep path heading to the wall, you see a shorter wall with an overhanging face.  On the left of this is a short arete and upper face that Jon Sykes bolted and apparently climbed. You kind of grab the arete, step on it where possible, but generally the lower 20 feet of this line is dominated by your body getting sucked down and right into the overhang where there are very limited right foot opportunities, and then grappling with the strange broken cleft above the overhang to find good enough hand holds.  All the while your left foot and leg is clawing at the arete to gain some stability.   Long story short, it's a sandbag at the 5.8 grade in the guidebook and perhaps even stiff at the 5.9 I am giving it here.   Not a bad climb but also not a "warmup" unless you already did gymnastics at home before coming to the crag.
content.location: Basically the first bolted climb you see upon entering the Waternomee climbing arena.

content.description: Home to at least 7 climbs, 5.6 to 5.12a
